conclusion.summary: Model diversity does not reliably increase long-range semantic coherence. The effect of model diversity on DFA alpha is inconsistent across provocations (2 pairs support H1, 3 oppose). No statistically significant differences were found for any metric.
key_findings: Multi-model shows consistently lower curvature (medium effect size), suggesting more directed semantic trajectory
DFA alpha effect is provocation-dependent, not a general property of model diversity
Pairs 1 and 5 (success, profit) showed multi-model advantage; pairs 2-4 showed single-model advantage
High variability in alpha (std=0.87) indicates strong provocation-specific effects
limitations: Changed Luma model from phi3 to llama3.2 mid-experiment due to timeouts
Turn selection weighted random may have introduced confounds
Voice distinctiveness in single-model condition (llama3) appeared reduced
future_directions: Investigate provocation-specific effects: what makes some provocations favor multi-model?
Test with larger n to improve statistical power
Analyze qualitative differences in dialogue content
Consider alternative metrics beyond DFA alpha

model_configuration.note: Luma changed from phi3 to llama3.2 due to context length timeouts
